description:
KFC Korean fried chicken is crispy and coated in a tangy and sweet sauce that had us licking our fingers! At $13 for 12 wings with a kale salad, it was also a bargain. 

I need to come here again for the tater tots!
author: Mary F.

description:
I tried this food truck for the first time yesterday. 
They came over to Foster City. 
Anyways, I love Bibibom bowl , #1 on there menu.
I think that is how you spell it , well the food had no taste to it . 
I even put extra sauce on it , thinking probably the spicier the better but wrong . 
I had about 5 bites, It was just tasteless. 
I will not try this place again, if I want Korean food I will just drive 5 mins. From my job and have their delicious food! 
I was disappointed in this food!
author: Mizy C.

description:
I ordered the bibimbap with bulgogi beef.  Decent sized bowl for $12.02.  Looks and tastes fresh.

I did have a big piece of cartilage in my beef which is not acceptable for making me pay a premium for my protein choice.

But, if they come back to my parking lot, I'll definitely stop by.  I'll just order some other meat.
author: Brooke R.

description:
I got to try Korean Bobcha recently at Off The Grid at Devils Canyon in San Carlos this past Friday. I ordered the BIBIMBOP with BULGOGI. It was huge! Lots of rice topped with shredded veggies, generous heaping of meat, and a fried egg (no extra cost). After tax it was only $12 and it was basically two portions. No extra cost unless you want to add Korean Fried Chicken as you protein (extra $1). Bulgogi meat was tender and well marinated. I loaded up on their orange sauce and a little red sauce.

My friends ordered the TOTS -- both Cali version and truffle bacon version. These are more like appetizer size but were loaded with all the toppings. I got a good whiff of the truffle flavor from my friend's dish even though it was across the table.

Looking forward to ordering more from this truck if I run into it again at an OTG. I want to try the boneless KFC or other meats on top of the bibimbop.
author: Bonnie Z.

description:
Came upon this truck because there was a "Lose Your Wallet" event promoting Apple Pay in downtown Burlingame, and Korean Bobcha was a participating vendor. Even though there were many people in line, they worked very efficiently and got the food out quickly. The lady who was taking orders was also calling our numbers for pickup, and she was a rockstar. We had a choice of three items and we could choose from three different proteins - bulgogi beef, spicy pork, sweet soy chicken. 

Cup Bob - zucchini, lettuce, garlic and magic sauces over steamed rice
Bob Burrito - bacon kimchi fried rice, pineapple, sweet sour cream, lettuce, magic sauce
Bibim Bob - mushrooms, beansprouts, zucchini, red cabbage, carrots, and lettuce over steamed rice with fried egg on top and magic sauce

Consensus was that the bulgogi meat was the tastiest, and the Bob Burrito was the favorite. The spiciness of the kimchi fried rice complemented the sweetness of the bulgogi, and the sweet sour cream they put in was a perfect addition that wasn't too tart like usual sour cream. Korean fusion and "Korean Mexican" isn't a new thing, but Korean Bobcha does it very well and we really enjoyed our lunch today. As this was a promotional event, I don't know what the normal price is for these items, but I would definitely choose this truck again if cost was reasonable.
author: Nicole M.

description:
I had to go to City Hall to drop off something and saw that they had food trucks across the way. I was hungry and saw Bobcha had a queue so of course I had to queue up as well!

I ordered #1, Bibimbop with fried tofu, brown rice and kimchi for $13. I only waited a few minutes and got my order. It was a large portion with carrots, mushrooms, bean sprouts, purple cabbage, regular cabbage, pickled cucumber and kale. It was so large and filling and I couldn't finish it but SO inhaled the rest of it. 

It's the first time I ordered with Bobcha but I really, really want to try the Bobcha tater tots next time.
author: Nette T.

description:
Food trucks at Devils Canyon, a Friday night ritual. LOVED the beef burrito "Cali style" with an egg. The Man got the spicy pork tacos. We split both, I'm so happy. 

Korean food and Pineapple lager, thank you mam! 

Ps. Cali Style has tator tots with cheese instead of rice...hella yes. Ate too fast to get a photo.
author: Susan K.

description:
Quite good Bibimbob, fresh, ample.  I should dock two stars, but practicing moderation, I'm only pulling one.  A huge bowl of meat, good rice, fresh veggies and an egg... but they charge extra for kimchi??  Let that soak in a moment.  Well, maybe you could go with it, suffering only minimal shock, if at least it was a major addition and flavor shift for the dish.  But you know what they give you -- gave me, anyway -- for a dollar?  I'm not kidding about this:  

About a tablespoon. I took a photo.  

Seriously.  Really.  True.  For honest.  And that that airborne dusting of Kimchi costs you a dollar more.  How much is a perilla leaf -- three?

W
T
F
, Dudes?
author: B R.

description:
The food here is DELICIOUS! 

But beware, it is definitely not the healthiest choice (ha ha). Actually, not even remotely healthy. 

The portions here are huge though, which is great! You can split it for lunch and dinner. I got the bulgogi tater tots the last time they visited our site, and man, I actually finished everything because it was so yummy (but oh how I regretted doing that).
author: Angelina H.

description:
The first time I tried this food truck, I had the curry tots and they were amazing! Just a good amount of curry powder flavor on it and the tots were extra crispy just as I like it. What made it more amazing was their orange sauce!! So good, I'd buy a bottle of it.. 

I recently tried this place again and ordered the bob cha tots which are tater tots with bulgogi on top and drenched in different sauces and green onion. In my opinion, this was good, but a bit too heavy for me. The sauces were really heavy and the meat was also very rich in flavor and a little too much for me. Next time, I'd prefer to get just the regular tots without meat so I can fully enjoy the tots and that bombbb orange sauce. 

I would also like to try the bulgogi burrito next time. My coworker really enjoyed it and said the orange sauce to go with it, really made a huge difference. 

P.S. Don't skip on that orange sauce!
author: Bailey L.

description:
I don't know what took me so long to try this food truck. I'm so glad they were nearby my office today because I was craving fried chicken and rice! 

I ordered the option with choices of two meats, rice, and kale salad (I think it's the Cup?). I got bulgogi chicken and Korean fried chicken for an extra dollar. They were both so good, especially with the fried egg, which was another $1.50. I didn't like the kale salad too much.. I think the kale could've been massaged more, but also it's really hard to beat the taste of fried chicken! The fried chicken had a sweet and spicy sauce, and the bulgogi chicken was delicious with their Magic Sauce.

Service was really quick! There were at least 6 people ahead of me, and after ordering, I only waited no more than 5 minutes. 

My total meal with tip costs around $14. The portions were a lot for me that I ended up saving half for dinner.  And I'm glad there wasn't a lot of rice... At first I felt it wasn't enough, but it actually was just right because I would've been full much faster.
author: Vira P.

description:
It's hard to find good Korean food.  It can be hard to find good food truck food as well.  However, I was delightfully surprised when Korean Bobcha catered last week.  We were served veggie dumplings, japchae, and make your own bibimbap bowls with an assortment of veggies, BBQ chicken, BBQ beef, and sauces.  

The dumplings were lightly fried and filled with tofu and other veggies.  They were batch cooked so they had that slight bit of toughness to them but still tastes great, and be forewarned, always go for a meat or seafood dumpling, yet kept getting more of these.  The japchae wasn't overly greasy and was one of the better ones I've had.  The chicken was less fatty and had more flavor than the beef, so I'd recommend sticking with the chicken.  The kimchi bacon fried rice had lots of potential but felt that it was very bland.  Couldn't really taste any of the kimchi or diced up bacon.  Veggies were fresh.  Didn't care for the sauces too much besides the normal hot sauce.  

I've seen the truck at Off The Grid and the food truck stop on 2nd Street but never tried them before today.  If I see them around and the Korean food craving hits, I'll definitely hit up their truck.  BBQ chicken, japchae and veggie dumplings FTW!
author: Cat C.

description:
Got the Korean Bobcha at Off the Grid and it was a real hit for me and my friends. The bulgogi meat was flavorful and tasty and the price was descent for the amount of food that you got. 

-Bobcha tots: crispy tater tots topped with tender bulgogi beef, kimchi, and cheese. Probably one of the best things on the menu if you're looking for a great bang for your buck! // 12.00 +tax

-Cup Bob: Tasty rice bowl with two choices of meat (we got bulgogi and Korean fried chicken) and kale slaw. The bulgogi really is a winner at this truck but with the Korean fried chicken I just wasn't as impressed. My boyfriend ate all the kale before I got to try any so I'm going to assume it has good flavor, especially because my boyfriend never eats vegetables. // 10.00 + tax
author: Emily T.

description:
My all time favorite asian-fusion place in San Francisco.

I can't express how much I like the food here! I still remember the day (like a few years ago man)  I tried this place randomly. I have been hunting this place down for a year now and I'm so happy I found it. Similar to HRD, they have pineapple in their burritos..but OMG this place man. The SAUCE and the bulgogi meat, seriously blows every one else out of the competition! Came here with my coworkers and even they couldn't pass up this place! The tots + chicken looked delicious, DEFINITELY going to have to try them out next.

Will be back + I'm looking forward to updating you guys on my favorites!
author: Melanie T.

description:
Food truck review. 

Bobcha tots (Bulgogi, cheese, sauce) - 3/5
KFC - 2/5

Overall, "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description: Just a tad spendy given what you get, in my opinion, but there's no denying that most of the items here, whether the bobcha burrito, KFC, or tots, are quite solid and reasonably tasty. The choices for your meats are fairly standard, like spicy pork, bulgogi beef, or bulgogi chicken. Depending on where this truck is at any given time (usually an Off the Grid event in the West Bay or along the Peninsula), it's worth checking out if other trucks are even more crowded.
author: Vincent L.

description:
WOW! I can confidently say that this is the best food I have ever had from a food truck. I tried Bobcha at Off the Grid when I was at Devil's Canyon on a Friday night. It was an easy choice, as others in our party were raving about it, and it had by far the longest line out of any of the food trucks. 

I LOVED the Bobcha tots, which are tator tots topped with bulgogi, kimchi, cheese, and sauce. Talk about a party in your mouth! The bulgogi burrito was also amazing, and tasted great with the magic and hot sauces (both delicious!). Despite the long line, service was really quick and we got our food in no time. 

Bobcha definitely does Korean fusion right...I will absolutely be back for more!
author: Chloe Z.

description:
I got the bobcha burrito.  Delicious and huge. 
The curry fries are overpriced and have a bit more curry powder than necessary but good.  Get the magic sauce" makes everything even better. 


I hope they  Come more often to civic center. Portions great. Quality delicious.
author: David C.

description:
Went to the food trick at Civic center today, and ordered the Cali style burrito. Unfortunately i waited until i got back to my office before i realized they just gave me the regular one. I heard the cashier call Cali style out but they just probably forgot. I think they charged me a little extra for it too. My total was $12 something after tax. I believe the regular is $10 +tax

Make sure to check your burritos before you leave if you ask for extras or changes!

Other than that the regular burrito is pretty decent..
author: Galen W.

description:
Looking back at my "food trucks list", I had no idea it had been so long since I last reviewed a food truck!  Which is odd, since it doesn't seem like it's been all that long, but it kind of makes sense at the same time.  Now that I think about it, it does seem like it's been a while since I hunted down a truck to try.  I mean, it's not like there are places where food trucks congregate everyday.

Oh wait...

After finally checking out SoMa StrEat Park (sidenote: my autocorrect is now forever ruined), I was eager to see what variety of trucks awaited us.  Unfortunately though, not many were still open when we arrived (it was only 8pm!), so our choice was essentially made for us.  However, even if that wasn't the case, we likely would have ended up at Bobcha anyways.  While the menu may be standard for a Korean food truck (Korean burritos, tacos, nachos, etc.), it was also the most appealing out of everything we saw.

-- NACHOS - Bulgogi Beef, Kimchi, Lettuce, and Cheese on Tortilla Chips with Hot and Magic Sauces
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/bobcha-south-san-francisco?select=tuXgn9UbtKttgTgQGzK8eg)
This was one good looking order - a bed of tortilla chips covered with a generous mound of meat and cheese.  The bulgogi was juicy and tender and I liked the combination of the two sauces.  However, I wasn't a fan of the chips; the taste was mostly fine, but I wish they had been thicker, as it didn't take long for them to become soggy/flimsy.

-- BOB BURRITO - Bacon Spicy Fried Rice, Lettuce, and a Choice of Meat (Bulgogi) with Magic Sauce
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/bobcha-south-san-francisco?select=WI6-2BkRMvSlgElGzmdGZg)
In hindsight, I should've tried another meat, but more of the bulgogi suited my taste buds just fine!  I liked the meaty, saltiness of the bacon as well, though the fried rice wasn't as spicy as I had hoped.  Still, everything was pretty good.  Just make sure to add kimchi (+$1)!  Sadly, I forgot to with mine and it really could've used that pungent acidity to balance out the flavors.

Although there's no shortage of Korean/Asian Fusion food trucks around the Bay Area, Bobcha is a pretty solid entry, albeit not super unique.  There may not be one signature dish or element to their food, but I thought the food was pretty solid overall, even if the chips still kind of bug me  In the end though, the most important thing is that, despite how they were one of the only available options available to us, they didn't let us down!
author: Mike L.

description:
Whoh ah we going to do tolunch, Bubba Bo Bobcha Brain?

The same thing we do every truck, Ajumma... try to burrito the WORLD.

At sounds woike a goo i ea Bubba Bo Bobcha Brain!

noyahsrsly other truckrritos should be this way
moist n tasty [check]
not mostly filler / rice [check]
deece price [check]

i'd eat here more often if i saw it more
author: Dan B.

description: Guys are kind, food is so delicious. The little cashgirl was so cute and bright and the bibimbop she recommended was awesome.
author: Changmin L.

description:
Decent food truck, more like Korean fusion food, with burritos, tacos, and rice bowls filled with your choice of meat.

As with normal food trucks, they are low in fresh vegetables, so whenever I do get food from here it's my "splurge day" or "bad decision day". I like the variety of items they have - the marinade on the meats are decent, and the portions are quite large. Most of them come with their magic sauce, which is quite sweet.

In general I find their food not spicy enough unless I add extra hot sauce - which isn't a crime, since it's more accommodating that way - but I do like my Korean food spicy.
author: Alice C.

description:
I'm spoiled on Korean food, living in the East Bay. The bibobap gave off a funny taste. 

I think the onions were onion, which is weird cause onions are not a normal ingredient in bibobaps. The meat was tasty, and the spicy mayo sauce that I got on the side was good, but after that there were things to pick at.

The bean sprouts seems old and not clean. Then there is the white onion and red onion that gave a weird taste. The worst thing was the mixed greens, when I mixed it into a warm rice, it kind turns to mush.

If I am in the mood for a rice bowl, Bowl'd is delicious.
author: Mei L.

description: The korean fried chicken is a MUST. I always get cup bop with two KFC. The chicken is just amazing. Authentic Korean food never disappoints.
author: Lauren L.

description:
I am writing this as I finish my left over bob-cup. I got steak and chicken, added an egg on top for extra fun, and it comes with lettuce, rice, and their special sauce. I came to the Off the Grid event at the Minna tunnel with a friend on Wednesday and decided Korean was the best option of the day. It was deeeelish. The meat is tender, flavorful, and not fatty. The rice has a nice flavor with the sauce. The line wasn't awful and it wasn't a crazy long wait once I ordered. 
I've been wanting to try this truck every time I go to one of these events and was very happy I did! Will def go back for 2nds.
author: Lindsey P.

description: I saw a group eating a big pile of delicious looking fries, which turned out to be their Kimchi Fries, and ended up getting this. This ended up being more of a visually impressive dish, but still good if you're looking for nachos in the form of fries! The fries themselves there thick but quite soft, no crisp. They cover the fries in ALL of their sauces and it ends up being a hodgepodge of flavors, with the meat drowning in it. 3 stars.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Food truck review. 
Off the Grid in Daly City.

Bob burrito with chicken - I was craving a very savory Korean burrito. Sadly, this did not deliver. Added a fried egg for $1. It was so bland. The spicy rice was not spicy. The whole burrito in itself just didn't have any flavor. 

Hesitant to give their other menu items a try.
author: Serena F.

description: Discovered this gem at off the grid fort mason and I'm so glad I did! The tacos were amazing!!! They also have sauces that compliment the food but the food was so good didn't even need sauce!
author: Jenny E.

description:
There are a ton of Korean fusion options around the city and sometimes it feels like Korean Tacos/Burritos are more common than Mexican ones.  Hence, Korean fusion no longer gets the novelty star inflation and must be compared to other Korean fusion.  I just felt this place was ok, hence the 3-star.  Didn't seem as flavorful as its competitors.

Mandoooo~ (sic): These are called potstickers on the menu, but they are clearly deep fried instead of steamed & seared (so they stick to a pot).  Thin and long instead of typical dumpling shape.  Average filling, but the creamy spicy dipping sauce was nice. 

Bulgogi Burrito: The smoky bacon flavor within the bacon rice really dominated the burrito flavor profile.  At times it felt more Southern than Korean.  A little bit too much lettuce for my tastes.  The bulgogi was in long thing pieces; the meat was good quality but they could have used more sauce.  Felt a bit bland overall, maybe kimchi should be a default instead of a possible upgrade?
author: Adam B.

description: This used to be one of the best food trucks in SOMA. It still is pretty good but there has been a noticeable drop in quality in the last 6 months. Maybe it would help to revive the old menu? the protein was a bit hard to chew the last time I got food from here.
author: Saideep S.

description:
Bobcha is a pretty common vendor in the SOMA Street Eats food truck park and I've seen their truck a few other places. Probably my favorite dish here is the Kimchi Fries. These are french fries covered with you choice of their meats, spicy sauce, cheese, and Kimchi (of course). I've tried it with a few different meats and everything has been good. Most people probably default for Bulgogi which is good, but all have been good. Next time I think I'm going to try the spicy pork. 

The quality is as good or better than a lot of food trucks and the prices are reasonable (again for food trucks). Some food trucks can be pretty mediocre and expensive, but I think Bobcha is better than average. The prices have gone up a little since the first time I went, but again I'd say they're on par with other food trucks. My favorite Kimchi Fries used to be $9 and they recently went to $10. I can't swear to it, but I thought the first time I went they were like $7 or $8. 

If you see them give them a try and you won't be disappointed.
author: Scott L.

description:
I've only had Bobcha at SoMa StrEat Food. I wasn't crazy about Bobcha when I first tried it, but it grew on me. Bobcha is one of the more satisfying options at SoMa StrEat, so I kept going back. 
Utilizing Korean ingredients in some type of burrito or taco is becoming ubiquitous, but this type of Asian fusion never appealed to me. Their menu options resembled that of a Mexican eatery, since most of the items include the same ingredients, just constructed in different ways. Same filling, w/ or w/o tortilla, you choose a meat option, pay an extra couple of bucks to add an egg. It didn't sound too exciting to me. Then I realized Bobcha serves food that just grows on you, like how some people can eat an entire bag of chips without even thinking about it. You may not love chips, but you keep going back.
Mr. Joy goes for Bobcha whenever we're at SoMa StrEat. No surprise there, he usually downs a bag of chips in one sitting too.

Bob Burrito w/ Bulgogi Beef - bacon spicy fried rice, lettuce, magic sauce:
I tried a bite, not bad. Then another, pretty good. Would I get this again? Yes. A little spicy.
I don't know what's in the magic sauce, but it is pretty sweet. Either that or it was just the bulgogi that was sweet. Bacon fried rice doesn't sound so exciting. I mean, I put bacon in my fried rice all the time, but it is pretty tasty too. I just didn't like the soggy lettuce in the burrito. The burrito just worked because the ingredients were seasoned well and full of flavor. Although I wouldn't mind if they took it down a notch with the sugar. 

Cup Bob - lettuce over steamed rice, magic sauce:
It's what you'd expect, pretty much the same thing as the burrito sans tortilla. It's nice to order something from a food truck you can eat with a fork and spoon.

Kimchi Fries - bulgogi beef, kimchi, lettuce, melted cheese, magic & hot sauce over fries:
Messy & gooey. You kind of need a fork for these, to be able to try the different ingredients in one bite. It was fun to try, but I wouldn't order it again. The spicy flavor and the tanginess of the kimchi kind of made the mixture taste a little like Frank's hot sauce. Does anyone else feel that way? Nope? Just me? Ok.

So it's pretty good for street food. I won't develop cravings for bulgogi beef in tortillas anytime soon, but the burritos are tasty. Not a bad price at around $9. It fulfills what I look for in a food truck - food you don't usually find in a restaurant that you can eat on the go.
author: Joy W.

description: I always go for the Cup bob with bulgogi and spicy pork. The quality and portion are both on point; this is the only Korean food truck where I tried the meats and did a double take because they tasted exactly like how my mom used to make them. Not overly sweet or salty.
author: Susie K.

description: Whether it's here or at SFO, the Kimchi fries are basically crack and the best value is the Cup Bob. Bacon spicy fried rice is always a worthy add.
author: Mike V.

description:
Today was the first time I saw Bobcha at OTG Fort Mason so I decided to give it a try. There was not much of a line when I got there around 6:30 so that was nice. 

I ordered the Bob cup/bowl and picked beef bulgogi and pork katsu and my choice of meats. I upgraded my rice to the spicy bacon fried rice as well. All the meats were on the fatter side with a lot of visible fat. Some people like that, but I was not a fan. Despite that, the flavoring of the food was good and I had a pleasant experience. 

The price came out to about $10. I thought it was probably not worth that much. Maybe $8-9 would be more fair. I don't know if I would want to come back, especially with so many tasty options at OTG.
author: Lydia H.

description:
After touring the ship from Fleet Week, my friend and I decided to get some food since we were starving. Luckily, there were food trucks nearby and decided to get Bobcha.

What was confusing was that there were no prices on the menu... Wtf? We ordered two bulgogi beef burritos and two drinks and the price was unbelievable high.

The lady who took our orders was rude as well which made our experience unfavorable.

The only reason why this isn't getting a 1 star was because the food was actually good.

SUGGESTION: post prices.
author: Aj C.

description:
It's been a while since I last wrote my review for Bobcha, so I figured it'd be worth writing a update since I've stopped by a few more times to try their other menu items.  I really like how they've completely expanded their menu and added more options to customize their food items.  Now they have burgers, tacos, and kimchi fries, and even nachos!!

I've had their Cup Bob and their Bulgogi Burger.  Both were pretty good and pretty satisfying.  The Bulgogi Burger alone is a hearty meal even with it being without fries.  

Bulgogi Burger -- http://bit.ly/1kuJi9e
Bulgogi Marinated Beef Burger with Cheese, Lettuce, and Magic Sauce
This was one big and messy burger!  Very juicy, though I didn't really taste the Bulgogi marinade from the burger.  

Where Bobcha totally won me over was their Spicy Bacon Fried Rice and how they included it into their Bobcha Tacos.

Bobcha Tacos with Bulgogi Chicken --  http://bit.ly/1reZ86p
2 soft tacos with spicy bacon fried rice, choice of meat, lettuce, magic sauce, and onion.
Because they included their spicy bacon fried rice, it definitely gave these tacos more substance and they didn't skimp on the meat which was awesome.  Every bite was full of bulgogi chicken and spicy bacon fried rice.   No fillers.  I'm definitely coming back for more of these!

I'm glad to see that Bobcha has made these additions to their menu.  It may be jumping the shark a little bit, but their flavors still very unique to differentiate themselves from all the other Asian fusion food trucks out there.
author: Rodney H.

description:
Making Mexican-[insert another cuisine here] fusion street tacos and burritos seems to be the norm for food trucks. Bobcha fulfills that concept with their Korean-style tacos and burritos. But they also offer burgers, nachos, fries, and the more conservative and traditional bibimbap.

Unfortunately, if the "Bob Burrito" is reflective of the quality of Bobacha's other menu items, then I doubt I'd revisit this food truck any time soon. For nearly $11, the Bob Burrito contains spicy bacon fried rice, lettuce, and a choice of meat. I chose beef bulgogi for my meat and added a fried egg for an additional $1. The egg was decent, but cooked to a medium-well. The bulgogi was tasty, but salty and extremely greasy. And the spicy bacon fried rice added just a mild kick, though I wish there were more bacon pieces. The "magic sauce" they slathered all over the meat in the burrito made the entire meal ridiculously greasy and heavy. I ended up tossing the tortilla wrap because it was saturated with so much oil.

I feel like Bobcha lost all aspects of Korean food by drenching everything with their magic sauce. It was quite disappointing, as I thought I'd really enjoy their food.
author: Priscilla W.

description:
Here's what you need to know about Bobcha. Do yourself a favor and get the kimchi fries - they are life-changing! I'm a huge fan of kimchi and bulgogi beef and potatoes are basically my favorite food group so it was worth giving them a shot. I am SO glad I did. Bulgogi beef, kimchi, melted cheese, magic sauce, and hot sauce. Sweet and spicy and savory. 

So like I said, get the kimchi fries, you won't regret it!!
author: Teresa C.

description:
Seems like everything is a "fusion" in San Francisco and Korean Bobcha is no different. 

I got the spicy pork tacos and it came with  three small tacos, filled with kimchi fried rice, spicy pork, and topped with lettuce. The kimchi fried rice adds an interesting texture and flavor. They also have hot sauce to make your food spicy but I didn't think the hot sauce was spicy at all.
author: Anny T.

description:
As I have gotten older, and my metabolism has slowed to about half speed, I have had to make some very unfortunate sacrifices, including downgrading my carb intake from thick sliced white bread and an extra serving of Japanese rice every day, to veggies and wheat bread or other alternatives. 

Ofcourse for the sake of my mental sanity I  have my occasional cheat day, and when I do I want each gram of carbs and sugar to be really worthwhile. 

I was sad when I spent that day at Bobcha.

Bacon Bulgogi Burrito ($7.75) add egg ($1) - 2 STARS. This burrito, which should by default include both kimchi and an egg ($1 extra each), was dissatisfying but large. The meat was low quality, but worse yet was the overly sweet red sauce that ruined the entire burrito. It was chock full of very mediocre non-bacony rice, and the very hard  cooked egg was no saving grace.

John's Snack Deli is still by far my favorite spot for a Korean Burrito. Save your money and daily carb/calorie intake and head somewhere else if you find yourself at Soma Streat Food Park.
author: Jess C.

description:
I checked out Bobcha at Off the Grid in Fort Mason because I was curious to taste their Kimchee Fries. Hesitant at first at how expensive the fries are- they're about $10 each- I still waited in line with my friend to get them anyway. Unfortunately, the line was hella long and it took us about 30 minutes before we could reach the front.

After about 5 minutes of waiting, we were handed our glorious kimchee fries. I was actually surprised at how much they gave us! For 10$, you do get your money's worth from the large portion size. Unfortunately though, the kimchee just didn't mix well with the fries. All the sauces together gave this interesting sweet flavor to the fries that just didn't taste like a natural kimchee sauce. It wasn't spicy nor was it flavorful. However, I did like the meat alongside the crispy fries but I probably wouldn't waste my time waiting in line for Bobcha.

Just a sidenote, I like how they tried adding "Bob" to all their dishes, but they could totally be more creative (like Bobrito), but who am I to judge?

Eat well and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
You've had kbbq and burritos separately I bet! Bobcha does you a favor and mush them together! And well.. Its freaking amazing!

Their Bob Burrito is a must have! It consists of spicy kimchi fried rice with their sweet beef bulgogi ( or the meat of your choice! Vegetarian option also available) and lettuce - $9.75
But you definitely must get the additional topping of fried eggs - $1.00 in it because well.. You just have to!

This food truck is kind of like the Korean version of sushiritto or senor sisig, they're all good! So you gotta try it when you go to Off the Grid!

Cheers!
author: Inge C.

description: Their burritos run on the sweeter side. Perhaps that's the taste their usual clientele prefer, but I was hoping their spicy pork would've had more of a kick. Perhaps some more gochujang or red pepper flakes in the sauce is needed. Or perhaps the pineapple is just too sweet and it's blocking out any hints of spice. They have other items I am interested in trying, but probably won't be reaching for a burrito anytime soon.
author: Binh P.

description: Big fan of the Bob Burrito with bulgogi.  The beef is really well marinated and, combined with the fried rice, makes for a really flavorful burrito.  Especially for the price, I have a hard time passing up Bobcha whenever I'm at the Soma Streatfood Park.
author: Simon L.

description:
W.O.W is all I can say about Bobcha! 

I saw them at Off The Grid: Fort Mason amongst the other food trucks & tents around, but this one caught my eye. Mexican w/ Korean fusion - I had to try them out. I ordered their Kimchi Fries which was a popular thing on their menu. It came out fairly quick considering how busy they were at OTG, & after receiving my load of Kimchi fries & taking my first bite into it, I literally rolled my eyes in amazement! Fries were crispy&hot, cheese was gooey, kimchi added a nice crunch, bulgogi was tender & flavorful,& the magic sauce had a nice spicy kick to it. I ate the whole thing w/ a happy smile on my face.

Overall, awesome food! Would def like to come back to try out their other stuff. Definitely check them out!
author: Trina N.

description:
I passed the Streat Food Park on my way home from San Francisco last week and just had to explore it the next time I was out here. We walked into the park and I quickly spotted two of my favorite things in the world fused together. I just had to try it.  

I ordered the Bulgogi Burger from Bobcha and I must say that this was one of the juiciest/tastiest burgers I have ever had.  Despite what you may think from the name of the burger, there is in fact no Bulgogi steak in this dish. The hamburger patty is actually marinated in a Bulgogi sauce and you can tell with every bite. The toppings include shredded lettuce and finely grated cheese. For an extra charge you can add an egg.  For 8.50 this is an amazing burger. My only complaint was that a side of fries is not included. Other than that, this is a must try the next time you see Bobcha around SF.
author: Danny G.

description:
Korean take on a number of fast dining options e.g. burgers and burritos.

We had a group of people here.

Vegetable tempura was good and crispy. A bit heavy on the battering but tasty.

I actually did the traditional bulgogi with beef. It was good with a nice selection of vegetables.
author: Felix C.

description:
They've been coming to our Off the Grid a lot lately and today, I had the Bob Cup with beef and pork and the bacon fried rice.  It was huge for $9.75.  It fed me for two meals.  The food was amazing.  I was expecting it to be overly sweet (like the burritos can sometimes be), but it was perfect.  Huge chunks of fatty pork and huge servings of ground beef.  I couldn't taste the bacon in the fried rice, so maybe they can work on that, but the kimchi sauce made it taste great either way. 

Def my favorite truck of the OTG days now.
author: Richard T.

description:
HEADLINE:  The Korean Senor Sisig.

(I feel a lot of eyebrows raising about the statement above - There's a pig with a knife, staring me down.)  

I'm a big fan of the food truck experience.  I kind of stumbled across Bobcha by accident one day as I was heading to do an errand.  As I came across UN Plaza Off the Grid, I decided to do a bit of looking.  The line for Bobcha was short.  As it happened, I had tried Korean tacos recently for the first time at SAM's on Market.  Love the flavor.  Love Bulgogi.  Love whatever the crazy Korean Hot Sauce is.  (We'll come back to that.)  So, why not get some more K-Tacos.  I gave it a whirl, and it was one of those Magic moments where you take a bite of food and just say, "****.  That was good."  They offer three choices of meat:  Ground Angus Bulgogi Beef, Pork and Chicken.  The tacos are corn, with a little rice, meat, cabbage, onion and a spicy sauce.  The order comes with two for $6.50, and you can add a third for $2 more (Do it).  If you have three, it's filling.  Now, the flavors are good - particularly the meat.  But, here is the kicker:  Magic Sauce.  It's Magic.  I'm not sure exactly what is in it - it's spicy and sweet.  I surmise that it is a combination of Sirancha and Hoisan Sauce.  But, it is a flavor explosion.  The Magic Sauce is the bomb.

I've also tried the Bulgogi burger, which is a Bulgogi-marinated Patty with cheese, lettuce, onion and Magic Sauce.  I added the egg.  Very good, and for as much as it was dripping with flavor, it was surprisingly manageable  in a food truck setting.  (Note to Food Trucks:  Whatever kind of sandwich you serve, put it on bread/bun that is big enough to eat without the filling falling out and making a mess.)  

There are some other good things on the menu.  I hate to go back to work in the afternoon with an impending food-coma, but they also have delicious looking Bobcha Burritos - and I really want to try one with Kimchi and an Egg added.  Gotta head over to the weekend setup at SOMA Stre-eat Food Park.  

My one admonition:  Repeat factor.  Had Bobcha for the third time today.  It was still very good, but some of the luster came off knowing just how tasty it was going to be.  I'll also add that I can see how people could find the Magic Sauce a bit cloying, if the sweet/spicy thing isn't their thing.  That said, I think Bobcha delivers good food, reasonable prices for what you get, and I really think the service and staff are terrific.  Super nice.

Living in SF, I've had occasion to try a lot of good food - and a lot of good Asian food, in particular.  I won't lie, I'm not an expert.  5-Stars may be pushing it a little based on the lack of range I've had with Korean food.  That said, Bobcha gets to keep 5-Stars from me until I find the next level.  We'll see if it stays at 5-Stars.
author: Adam S.

description:
Very tasty. The nachos were pretty tasty. The fried shrimp were a little more standard and unimpressive, though still tasted good enough.

I've had better Korean-style nachos and fries at other food trucks (whose names unfortunately escape me at the moment), but Bobcha's offerings were still fully enjoyable. Perhaps a silver or a bronze medal if we're making this a contest.
author: Sean B.

description: The Bob Burrito (regardless of which meat) with spicy & magic sauces is revelatory: really darn good!
author: Matt L.

description:
I'm with Augusto - the Bulgogi tacos were just alright. I love Bulgogi and could eat it all day everyday, so I was stoked when they had the option. I snagged two tacos expecting total bliss but was disappointed with the ground beef.

I would probably try something else next time.
author: Melissa W.

description:
Tried the Cup Bob during a week day. Portion sizes were generous and food was not too greasy.

Minus two stars for bad service.

My coworker added a fried egg to her Cup Bob and they forgot it. Instead of just fixing her order like any normal business, they gave her order away and said they would remake it. 

But they decided to take half a dozen new orders first! 

As a result, we waited 20 minutes longer for their mistake with no apology.

This was probably a result of Senor Sisig arriving late and Bobcha trying to capitalize on as much business as possible instead of doing the right thing.
author: Tina G.

description:
Great Korean food in a truck! I tried their Bi Bim Bop, and it was deliciousness in a box! 
Mashisseyo! 
Their potstickers were different, rectangles with a little hot sauce on them. Meh. I would like
to go back and try some other goodies, though! 
Found them in the Soma Food Truck area, 428 11th street, on Halloween night. They were participating in Truck or Treat. But I think they are based in South San Francisco. 
Kam sa ham nida!
author: Wanugee N.

description:
My FLAVORITE food truck! My husband just shook his head when I said it, but I don't care haha.

I used to do the cup bob, beef, egg, white rice. Simple. Delicious. (I get mine without lettuce cause apparently I still eat like I'm 10.) It was so perfect for me, sweet, a dash of spicy, yum. It was perfect.

One day I decided to try outside the box and into a burrito. Same stuff as the box but with Spicy Fried Rice and wrapped in a tortilla. I didn't know it could get better, but it did and now I'm addicted. There is just so much delicious flavor and it's easier to eat! No forks required. 

I mean yeah they are not cheap, typically food trucks are not cheap, but bobcha never makes me regret my decision. I don't even live in the city, but I've been making more trips there lately. 

I had initially found them at the treasure island flea, and even though I was tempted to try them, skipped them, probably a couple of times. Eventually I thought, I'll just try them. It's actually both a blessing and a curse. They are just so good I don't want to try any other truck.
author: Lisa L.

description: Cup Bob with egg - that is all. It's some kind of mystery of physics how they pack so much food into what looks like a very small box. But i am not a dainty eater by any stretch and i can never finish this thing. Which is ok, because it reheats really well. I always get a mix of bulgogi and spicy pork (not that spicy), but i bet everything is good. If you're looking for the best bang for your buck at the truck park, this is it in terms of both quantity and quality.
author: Erica W.

description:
All the meats here are quality and very well cooked.  The sauces they come with are flavorful and well balanced.  I especially like their hot sauce which has good kick and texture, a little grainy and heavy enough to coat but light enough to pour, and it has a hint of fermentation which I prefer over other which are usually in it.

The meats come dressed any way you like it, bibimbap, burrito, taco, pretty much whatever you'd want.  I prefer the cup bob without rice, plain and simple delicious meat on top a bed of lettuce.
author: Chris H.

description: These guys killed it during my work time lunch rush. There was a long line but it moved very quickly. Food came out fast and was really great. I ordered the 2 choice meat combo (bob cup) and the meat was marinated nicely and the flavors of the two meats blended well (bulgolgi and spicy pork) it came with fancy sauce on it but I put more on for good measure. Would definitely eat this again and maybe try the bimibop, it looked amazing as well.
author: Lauren B.

description:
Visited San Francisco for my first time and was told to go to the food truck festival (Off the Grid) at Fort Mason.  This food truck caught my eye so I decided to try something new...  Ordered the Kimchi Fries and the Bobcha soft tacos.  

Bobcha Tacos were yummy...  But The Kimchi Fries...  OMG!!!

The Kimchi Fries were delicious...  I have never had them before so I have nothing to compare them to but let me tell you that I have been craving them ever since...   So good and such a huge portion...  Enough for 2-3 people...

So good...  Hope to find some good Kimchi fries here in Miami...
author: Melba B.

description:
KOREAN IN A BOX
(3 stars)

Sadly to report... It gave me the runny #2!!!!

FOOD, tasty
PRICES, decent
SERVICE, quick

All these Korean mobiles have the same concept, Korean burrito, Korean nachos, etc. The only thing that caught my eye was affordable pricing and good portions. 

CUP-BOP ($7.75) - they should call it box-bop because it doesn't come in a cup. selection of two meats and rice and veggies. Anything extra to add in is $1 each, I got the kimchi. The Bulgogi resembled ground beef/chopped beef. But it tasted fine. The spicy chicken was spicy only cause of the overly excessive orange hot sauce. The kimchi was okay, tasted good with everything. I wish there was room to mix it together because I had to dig around just to get to the rice and veggies at the bottom. Great portion, just condensed in a tiny box.

Will I be back? Sure, only if someone can hand me some Cottonelle wet-wipes. 

Until the next review....
author: Jane A.

description:
Korean Bob Cha is a food truck dispensing korean food in various vessels:
-bowls
-burritos.
-bibimbap
-fried shrimp
-burgers
-mandoo"potstickers"
2ish stars

eats: bobburrito with bulgolgi (8)
-lots of sweet tasting rice surrounding a few strands of tasteless  beef
-couldn't taste the beef, could feel the lettuce.
-not a good value
-picture of spicy pork shows more meat
-not sure this is korean food, maybe a panda express clone/wannabe.

crumbs:
-friendly service, 
-confused about their food value/prep.
-2 stars value, giving 3 stars for showing up. 
cash only
author: Victor G.

description: Get the Korean fried chicken and curry fries!! So so good. All breast chicken coated, fried and in their special sauce. I normally share as it's huge for 1 but so delicious l!
author: Allie S.

description:
I ordered the bulgogi kimchi fries and was disappointed. First let down, they use ground beef... and then cover it in weird, sweet wanna-be korean sauce. Then they add cheese...why add shredded cheddar cheese? Those things are on top of shredded lettuce that is now soggy. 
They should take the kimchi fries off the menu so people like me dont order it, hate it, then never try any of their other items out of fear its going to horrible like their kimchi fries.
The fries themselves were made to order and tasty though.
author: Brooke F.

description:
3.5 stars
A good food truck serving Korean-fusion items, I had the Korean Tacos, which were very good...sweet and slightly spiced beef including a zesty and flavorful rice.  While I can't say these were the best version of this popular street food, they were still good and satisfying.  The side of Kimchi was good.
author: Ken G.

description:
Got cha.

Two gigantic tacos overflowing with spicy chicken and lettuce.

Fried rice too if you are into it.

Less a taco and more a meal. Generous in size and flavor.

Well worth the $5 for the pair. 

Got more?
author: Jason B.

description:
One of the better food trucks out there. I work out in the SOMA, so I usually catch it when it's in the area (either at the G Food Lounge or the Townsend and 5th OTG).

As far as Korean flavors and taste, this stays true to the roots even though it's most popular items are fusion (i.e. the Kim Chee Fries, The Burrito, and Nachos).

The meat is seasoned well, very flavorful, and not dry (so far I've tried the Spicy Chicken and the Bulgogi Beef). It's probably better than some of the brick and mortar Korean spots I've been to. They have a special sauce (a mayo based spicy sauce) and a gochujang sauce to top most of their food items. For the price (especially for a food truck), I would say that the portions are also fairly generous.

Depending on how busy it is, it can be a bit of a wait (I've waited as little as 4 minutes but as much as 15 for my order). But no matter what, I'd still say it's worth it.

My only complaint (and it's really a nit) is that the Kim Chee fries should really have more Kim Chee in it. Not that I'm complaining since there's plenty of other toppings, but a little bit more would be nice.

If you're into Korean food and into the food truck scene, this place is definitely worth a try.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
Bobcha is a delicious, fast, and reasonably priced truck. They have a menu with good variety and a good selection of meats for their dishes. 

I generally get Cup Bob, a box packed with rice, lettuce, and two choices of meat, with spicy chicken and spicy pork. It also comes piping hot and is a delicious and filling box of meat.

Friends have gotten their bibimbap, bulgogi nachos, burritos, and tacos before and have enjoyed them as well.
author: Rajiv P.

description: Got to try this wonderful food truck because of Off the Grid. I got the Cup Bob with spicy pork and spicy chicken over a bed of steamed rice and lettuce. Satisfying lunch for sure. Their "magic sauce" is excellent.
author: Val K.

description: Bobcha, what can you even say to express how awesome this food truck is. I've had their amazing bulgogi beef burrito with Kimchi added and sometimes, not always, but sometimes a fried egg, more times than I can count. It is the best urban food log in the bay area. Yes, you can get classic burritos all over the place in SF and the greater bay but this, is something special. Everything on the menu is great but that burrito, I have literally dreamed about this burrito. Just buy the burrito, put Kimchi in it, don't forget the hot sauce!!!
author: Matthew H.

description: This place is amazing. Hands down one of the best food trucks I've tried out in S.F.  I got the burrito with bulgogi beef, and it was delicious! It went perfectly with the magic and hot sauce.  I'll absolutely be back for more!
author: Josh B.

description: I ordered the bulgogi nachos and burger. The nachos came out cold and meat seemed like minced up taco meat. I did not like the sweet flavor they put on top or that the cheese was unmelted, but the kimchi mixed in (which was very small) added a flavorful kick. The bulgogi burger had the same meat, but was very flavorful and not too sweet. I wish I added kimchi to the burger for an additional $1.25, because I think the kimchi would have made the burger very unique and give it more texture and spice.
author: Risa P.

description: I first met Bobcha at SoMa StrEat Food Park.  I had gone there because Senior Sisig was there and I had a craving.  As I was walking around checking out the other trucks I stumbled across Bobcha.  I love tacos and Bobcha had tacos.  Why not, I'll give them a shot and see what it's all about.  That's how it all started.  Now I faithfully stalk Bobcha around even more so than I did Senior Sisig.  I love their taco's also but what I love about Bobcha is that magic sauce.  I really feel like that sauce should be put on everything I eat now.  Pork Katsu, forget the katsu sauce gimme magic sauce!  Bobcha is so nice that they leave a magic sauce bottle out so people can take a cup or two just in case you need extra...which I always do.  This truck is definitely one of my most favorite trucks.
author: Scott T.

description: I love the chicken burrito with the magic sauce.  The owner is really nice and so dedicated to her business.  She's been suffering with back problems for quite a while and she still keeps working.
author: Trisha M.

description: This food truck is so good you have to try it for yourself to believe. My favorite is the Bob burrito with kimchee and their special beef sauce. Be sure to arrive before at noon, as the line is always long after noon.
author: Christina A.

description: If you want fried goods, it's a safe bet to go with the fried shrimp. LIGHTLy battered, well cooked. They give you a sauce that i didnt even use. Straight up panko like crust and shrimp flavor is all you. Need
author: Kim N.

description:
Favorite truck at Soma Streat Food Park because of its amazing flavors and how filling this is. My favorites are the burrito and the cup bob, both of which can easily feed 2. Truck personnel are also friendly, and the food comes out pretty fast.

FYI the bulgogi beef is ground but is actually really good on its own merits, so after getting over the initial disappointment from it being not what you expected, you can fully enjoy your meal.
author: Elaine S.

description:
Ok, no really, I loved the tacos. I got the Bulgogi chicken tacos, and had some fun with the sauces they offered on the side. Came with rice, lots of chicken, thinly shredded cabbage, cheese, and maybe some other goodies I couldn't readily identify, but still yummy. 

They were super quick, particularly for a food truck, and the tacos were straight forward but also super tasty.  Chicken was good quality, well seasoned, etc.

The customer service was polite and quick, prices were decent ($6.75 for 2 very hearty tacos), and basically in the world of food trucks, I'd say this is a good bet.
author: Teresa B.

description:
Easily my favorite food truck in SF. Literally everything is good. The bulgogi burger is one of the best burgers in the city. The Bob Burritos are awesome. The nachos are to die for.

Basically everything is good, and it's definitely a go-to any time it's parked near me!

Plus everyone is super nice.
author: Will G.

description:
When you are about to chew your arm off, you simply do not have the mental capacity to carefully weigh your options while standing in front of a dozen food trucks. You just don't. Korean seemed a safe enough choice, so I made a snap decision. Dire hunger trumped my burgeoning Yelp snobbery (a.k.a. always consult Yelp before ordering). 

Bobcha serves up Korean fusion fare in the form of burritos, burgers, tacos and rice bowls. I had the spicy pork bobcha tacos which came with spicy fried rice and shredded lettuce on a flour tortilla. The pork was tender and seasoned well, although maybe a tad too sweet for my liking. It certainly looked festive. The rice and spicy sauce blazed orange, the lettuce lent its happy green, and I had myself a Korean fiesta with every bite. Not too shabby for an impulse choice. Next time, I'm going for the bibim bob or maybe the bulgogi burger.
author: Racquel N.

description: Had the bulgogi beef burrito with fried egg and spicy bacon fried rice (hold the lettuce--it just takes up space)...but it didn't impress me. Not exactly a quick lunch either, for being 10th in line.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Got their bulgogi tacos. YUM YUM! So creative and bursts of flavor - it was good! One thing i thought was ehh was that there wasn't any sour or acidic/fruity components on the tacos. Just creamy, savory, salty - it needed some lime or lemon or orange zest of something! Besides that, i would like to go back for the cup bob or burrito!
author: Jane C.

description:
Eh Not bad, but not great. Bulgogi was disappointing because it was just ground beef. Not what I was expecting. Tasted fine, but who really wants ground beef instead of real beef. 
Nachos were a little weird. Maybe its my fault for getting nachos, but iceberg lettuce? Why lettuce? I know nachos are just stuff on top of tortilla chips, but this just seemed flavors were too mashed up with no cohesion. And the chips were just seemed like they were tostitos rounds.
Flavors were fine, but KoJa is waaay better. 
I only went here cause the line was longer at the other trucks. 
Otherwise I probably would have passed.
author: Augusto M.

description: This was the first Korean burrito I have ever had. It was really yummy and the side sauce they offer is delicious. I had the Spicy Chicken burrito and added on an egg. Definitely a filling meal and totally worth the price in my opinion. I would go back for another!
author: Caitlin Y.

description:
Review is based on their tacos.
Presentation: yum!
Taste: meh.

2 tacos per order. You can mix and match meats. I got the spicy pork and the bulgogi tacos. Meat tasted ok. The pork had a little bit of a weird stink to it. My main issue was just the overpowering flavor of their sauces. Everything else just got kind of drowned out, including the bacon rice that I was looking forward to tasting.

Some of the stuff on their menu looked pretty pricey. With the addition of a fried egg and/or kimchi, you're looking at a $10+ food truck item.
author: Will Z.

description: Went to off the grid at fort mason last night and tried their bob tacos? I believe that's what it was called. I got the spicy pork and it was sooo good! It came out to $7.34 for 2 tacos. Almost debated on getting some more before leaving to take home! Definitely coming back.
author: Tori M.

description:
I'm always open to trying new trucks and Bobcha seemed like a good bet at last night's OTG: North Beach. The Korean-inspired truck infuses their signature recipes to create such items as their bulgogi burger, as well as their own versions of burritos, tacos, and nachos. For most of their items, you pick your protein from a list including bulgogi beef, bulgogi chicken, spicy chicken and spicy pork. Bulgogi is a Korean sauce that tends to be on the sweet side.

I know there's no such thing as eating healthy at OTG. Nevertheless I felt getting a Bobcha bowl might be a better choice than a sandwich from Five Ten Burger. The Cup Bob allows you to pick two proteins, which are then served with steamed rice and lettuce with their magic sauce. I chose the bulgogi beef and spicy chicken and paid the $1 surcharge for brown rice for a total of $8.75. Drinks were $1.50.

A few minutes later, I got my box of food, which did look appetizing especially with their magic sauce. I was incredibly disappointed when I realized that half the box was filed with ground beef and not BBQ beef. The chicken was delicious. The beef I was not a fan of and ended up dumping out. I'm simply not a fan of ground beef. Once you get through your protein, you're rewarded with the steamed rice (brown rice in my case) and the lettuce.

It wasn't the best experience nor was it terrible. It's in the middle. I quickly ate through the delicious spicy chicken and brown rice, but the lettuce didn't add much to the overall box and felt like filler just to add volume. And for $8.75 I was left hungry and was back in line, but this time at Five Ten Burger.
author: Alexander E.

description:
wow wow wow!

so, along with my travels, of course i have to find some hot spots to dine and enjoy
this time however during our visit to San Francisco, my parents chose this truck while I was at Walker Stalker Con.
In the convention area in Fort Mason, about 6-7 trucks were lined up, and this one stood out to my parents
and damn was it a good choice!
coming from Los Angeles, Kogi is our choice for mexi-asian fusion and one of, if not the best food truck in LA

now in SanFran, Bobcha is the next closest thing!! (fair warning/legal disclamatory: this is not better or equal to Kogi, but it is still absolutely delicious, just under Kogi!)

my parents ordered three dishes: 

Bob Burrito with bulgogi beef, bacon spicy fried rice, lettuce, and kimchi.
we actually did nt have  chance to eat it fresh, BUT a few hours later in the hotel and damn was it amazing still! who knows how good it would be fresh! tender flavorful meat, delicious rice, (fyi, I usually HATE rice in my burritos) and crunchy lettuce and kimch; not too much tortilla and stuffed with everything!

kimchi fries: bulgogi beef, kimchi, lettuce, cheese, magic sauce. the french fries were ALL so crispy and perfectly golden fried! even under the meat cheese and sauce, it was still perfectly crisp! the beef was tender, juicy, and delicious, flavorful and spicy too; kimchi was crunchy and nicely spiced, and the magic sauce was not too spicy, hint of sirarcha, and perfect!

cup bob: lastly, this cup (more like a bowl) was bulgogi meat, chicken, rice, and lettuce with magic sauce
both meats, chicken and beef, were juicy tender delicious, as all the dishes were, rice was flavored nicely with bacon, sauce was great and very filling

all these dishes were phenomenal and for about $30? not bad for a food trucks nowadays considering the size of each portion!

highly recommend to tourists and locals
author: Anton E.

description:
We ordered the kimchi fries at the Treasure Island Flea Market.

The order came out piping hot and the fries were satisfyingly crisp under the gooey kimchi/cheese/awesome-sauce topping. 

The combination of flavors was something that touched every part of the palette and the item was also very filling.

It was a flavor explosion... I can't recall eating anything recently with this amount of texture and taste.
author: Richard H.

description:
This seems to be a trend in many cities across America, but I'm a fan of the Korean-Mexican mix food truck. I sampled both the kimchi fries (good, but I've had slightly better in Austin), and the burrito (ditto).

The flavors and portions are good, but I would have to slightly downgrade them since I've had slight better, but identical food in other cities. However, its very reasonably priced, and offers exciting flavors to those who haven't been introduced to this type of food.
author: Oliver Z.

description: Bob cha is without a doubt my favorite food truck! I love their spicy chicken and bulgogi beef in spicy bacon rice!
author: Tammy M.

description: I've been to this truck several times and it's bomb. The Kim chee fries are always my go to. So delicious and yummy. The sauce they add is great and the meat is tasty. Download the off the grid app to see where they're located! Always changes.
author: Daisy S.

description:
I don't know what took me so long to come experience the SoMa food truck park. II've been looking forward to it and finally made it here since we had some out of towners who wanted to give it a try. 

We decided to go to Bobcha, since it was the one with the longest line. Plus Korean + Tacos = awesome no?? 

I originally put this review at a 4 star right after we had the meal. But I'm not revising it since my husband who also ate here starting getting the runs a few hours after we ate here. I saw another review with similar comments. I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and assume it's just food sensitivity. 

This is what we ended up having... in which I took a solid bite out of my husbands burger to make sure you're not getting a 2nd hand review. 

Bugolgi beef burger with a fried egg  - So juicy and delicoious. But it's a big small for the price they charge ($8.75 for what looks like a slider). 

Bugolgi Nachos Special - kimchi, bugolgi, special sauce and nachos.. What's not to love?? I rest my case. 

I would go back again, but there's a lot more other food trucks in the area to try, so I will start with a 3 and work my way through.
author: Winny F.

description: I had the bulgogi tacos and they were yummy.  The good thing about the tacos is that they serve generous portions of meat so it is definitely worth the $5 price.
author: BestFoodTrucks B.

description:
Bobcha, Korean fusion food , Nothing stands out but also there's not much bad to say about it. Pretty standard prices, but I LOVED how big the portions was. You will be getting your money's worth. 

I had the Bob Burrito, bacon Korean fired rice, choice of meat, and lettuce. Let's just say you should be ready to eat because it was huge!  I added the egg and the kimchi to get the whole experience. Definitely recommend to spend the extra on the egg and the kimchi. As far as the rice, I thought it was a let down and over hyped. I felt that it was just rice that was tossed in the House sauce that's on the meat. 
The flavors are well balanced thanks to the sourness of the kimchi and the richness with the egg, everything just complements each other. Personally with out the kimchi and egg, it would be too boring because all you taste is the Korean sauce (the Korean ketchup).

Pro- great deal/big portion, solid Korean flavors.

Con- nothing stands out as far as Special bacon Korean Fried Rice. The three meats all taste the same. 

Food -3/5
Service - 5/5
Overall - 4/5 

If you are hungry and want a well rounded Korean burrito, I would come here in a heartbeat. Definitely recommend the kimchi and egg extras, makes a big difference. Loved how big the portions were for the standard food truck prices. Those who've tried Korean fusion food will think this is nothing special, but it's worth to eat
author: Drew W.

description: Had the bibimbob with bulgogi which was good, but I kinda expected more flavour. The hot sauce helped a bit. The serving portion was a pretty good size for the price.
author: Bianca C.

description:
I tried their BibinBob with kogi and at first i thought to myself..."i might have to find something else to eat..this isnt enough" I was so wrong. it was just right. The kogi was ok..would have preferred a different cut of meat for the $8 price tag plus and extra $1 for kogi. The taste was there but i do think the price should be lower. You get all the banchan at a restaurant for free. For $8 you gotta include the kogi.

oh and the girl taking orders looks like Sarita P. hahahahaha
author: Craig I.

description: I had a delicious bipimbap bowl with HUGE, tasty portions. The friendly and generous customer service was an excellent plus :)
author: K S.

description:
My mom, who is a very picky eater, loved their food! We're Koreans so we know how korean food should be like, and this place definitely hit the spot!

We got a cup bab and when we first heard it was $8.75, we kinda got hesitant cuz it was too pricey. However, it did not disappoint us at all!! Worth a lot more! We asked to put bulgogi, kimchi(they give you more if you want), and spicy pork and it was an amazeball!! Very juicy and the meats were all very tender. It was pretty big that my mom and I shared one bowl and we both got very full. The cashier was very friendly also. Highly recommend it!
author: Christina K.

description:
My husband and I stopped for lunch around Civic Center and this truck was a total surprise. It was so delicious I'm still salivating thinking about it. We ordered bulgogi and pork burritos and they deserve my 5 stars. It was juicy but not runny, warm, soft meat and crunch Kimchi combo was sweet and tangy with tiny kick from chili powder. Gochujang sauce was drizzled just the right amount. 

Go Bobcha! You are really authentic and I felt the love!
author: Ellen W.

description:
"Bob" meaning rice/meal and "cha" meaning car - roughly translating to "Food /lunch Truck." Ever since rumors of a Mexican/Korean fusion food truck made their way to the Bay Area, knock offs have appeared high and low.  NorCal first had its taste at the newfound fusion delicacy with the Bulgogi truck; however now that the Bulgogi truck vanished in nothingness and MogoBBQ 's popularity declining we feel like the days of the Korean Mexican fusion are gone with the wind.  Here's where Bobcha came in - rather than approaching the scene with a "cool/hype" vibe, Bobcha presents itself as a Mom + Pop Korean Fusion truck.  While MogoBBQ relied much on image and "hit and miss" menu items, Bobcha lets its items do the talking.   I tried the beef and the pork burritos and both of them were excellent!  Just enough meat to go with the vegetables and rice, the prices were pretty average for a food truck but I didn't have the buyer's remorse I usually experience from buying food truck meals.  

Definitely would have it again!
author: Ray S.

description: I had the cup bob and it was delicious. I had the spicy chicken and pork cutlet over rice and it was delicious. For $9, I would highly recommend trying this truck out if you happen to see it in action. Very good food at a reasonable price.
author: Scoot S.

description:
Thursday, the struggle is real,
day after hump day, overcast skies in the city,
two coffee kinda day, need some motivation,
should've gone to kaskade, redux,
seekin' excitement to get through the day, anything,
lunch time, off the grid,
fusion food trucks, located at UN plaza, 
stayin' politically correct, this Amurica, 
mad line with the homeless, refugee or gentrification,
360 to spot the selection, Korean food truck, 
played out or cliché? linin' up to find the answer, 
bobcha, you do or you don't or you will or you won't cha, 
go to off the grid downtown and eat it like a vulcha, 
gained a few pounds in my waist for ya, this the kinda beat that go wa ta ta, 
ra ta ta ta, ta ta ta ta ta,
sorry got carried away with the boredom, enough with sing-a-long, 
ordered bob cup, bacon fried rice, bulgogi, and spicy pork, 
90 percent protein, 10 percent concentrated power of will, 
was a bit disappointed, not a fan of grounded angus for bulgogi, 
the whole thing was a bit heavy, though probably my fault for pigging out, 
but bro, not even chipotle can get you three types of meat in one bowl, 
love the couples that work here, very friendly, 
will try again next time, better luck tomorrow
author: Roy C.

description:
Is this the same Bobcha truck that parks at the Streat Food lot in SOMA?  

If so, their Korean burger is AMAZING
author: Ezra C.

description: Best Korean food in SF without any doubt. I had bibimbob which is Korean traditional bowl. Mixture of assorted fresh garden salad, rice, and beef served with Korean style spicy sauce. Very flavorful. Simply the best. Vegetables cant get any fresher than this and there was plenty of beef in the bowl. Friendly staffs make my experience here even better!! If you have not try this spot yet, you dont know what you are missing. Check this place out
author: Min Yong C.

description: Tried their food from the jpop festival today. I got the cup Bob with bulgolgi and spicy pork and shared nachos with my friend. At first when I tasted the food it was very good. But then after a while it didn't taste so good. The spicy pork was ok good but the bulgolgi tasted like corned beef. Service was pretty quick and friendly.
author: Carmen L.

description: I tried lots of food truck and this is best truck period! Very tasty korean food and tons of portion of food. What else can you ask for??
author: Kwang Hee Y.

description: Meh.  Just tried their location at streatfood and it was just so so.  Got the bibimbap and it made me just crave some real, good bibimbap. Didn't help the food was lukewarm at best.
author: Susan Y.

description: Bibimbap was just okay. Ingredients weren't the right temperatures, too much sesame oil, virtually no other seasoning. The hot sauce was like ketchup. Portion size was decent.
author: Jay S.

description: Bibimbap was only ok- $1 extra for less than an 1/2 oz kimchee & $1 for brown rice. Iceberg lettuce was shredded and underneath some of the mushrooms/onions I think to make it look like there was more of the sides-filler lettuce? Sauce was good and available to dollop on as you please. I would give another 1/2 star if an option- for the sauce ;)
author: B B.

description: I had their burrito. I will say the meat is not as flavorful or as spicy as HRD and that is certainly lacking but they offer a good burrito. I think what makes their burrito special is the rice. It's marinated in some kinda sweet sauce so you get a nice kick of sweet and spicy in combination that you might not get with the other food in the truck. I would say that's what makes this truck remarkably good though the price ($10) is a bit hefty for a pretty small burrito.
author: Rohan D.

description: Skip this truck.  I tried a couple of their bowls, and it's nothing special.  No real flavor, meats were dry, combination of textures was off.  Wouldn't get food from this truck again, there are much better trucks.
author: Tadd L.

description: Went down to the SOMA Streat Food park and of all the options there, Bobcha called to me. Had the Bob Burrito with a fried egg and was in heaven. It was the best 'burrito' i've had in a long time. I definitely want to go back asap!
author: Chloe B.

description: We were at the food truck park in the city and this truck sounded the most exciting. For whatever reason, they had tooo many basic Mexican taco trucks at the park on this night. So, I ended up having a spicy pork burrito wit kimchee, bacon fried rice and special sauce. It was absolutely delicious!! Kimchee was nice and spicy, the fried rice didn't really have the bacon flavor I had envisioned, but it was good. We also ordered up the fried shrimp. Not great, but good. Special sauce that comes with it was sweet rather than spicy. It took a few bites to get over the sweetness of the sauce, but I enjoyed it. Extra star for customer service. The lady behind the window was super nice, asked me how my day was going and we had a nice chat before we did our business transaction. That was a nice touch and clearly she has a vested interest in the food. I came back to grab an extra cup for some hot sauce and she asked again if everything was good. It's a small thing to some, a pain to others, but kindness has killed greater man than I.
author: Hector G.

description: Their Bob Burrito (choice of Bulgogi Beef, Spicy Chicken or Spicy Pork) is really good. I recommend adding an egg, and getting a side of their sweet and spicy sauce. Goes good with a beer. =)
author: Jonathan B.

description: Food here is delicious! I had their tacos and  bulgogi burrito and both were very satisfying and good. I especially like how they give you the option to add an egg inside of your burrito.. Go for it, it's freaking yummy. The yoke of the egg is just perfectly cooked, where you can taste the egg yoke's creaminess.... Yes. It's good here. Oh yeah, the service is friendly as well. I appreciate that. Five stars!
author: Violet G.

description:
1.5 stars

thought i ordered the bibim bob but that's not what i got :(. 

i was excited that i had the option to have brown rice which i order. the menu said it would come with zucchini, mushrooms, lettuce, rice, meat and the picture had an egg. what i got was 2 kinds of meat over lettuce and brown rice. what happen to everything else? it tasted good (maybe i was hungry) but would have tasted better with the rest of the ingredients...sigh...live and learn.
author: Elaine Y.

description: Tried their Bibimbob, and it was ok. I would give them an extra star but they cheated me out of meat which i paid  extra for.  when i got back into the office to enjoy my meal with beef I had nothing but veggies with rice. and I AM NOT a vegetarian. I gotta have my protein..
author: Claudia E.

description: Delicious bibimbap prepared quickly and served at a reasonable price.  A perfect Sunday lunch.
author: Dan H.

description: I ordered bobcup ( spicy chicken & bulgogi ) added $1 for bacon fried rice.  I was expecting good meal for my lunch.  but after I opened the box, disappointed .....half of small box was grounded beef. never seen grounded " bulgogi. If I knew bulgogi is grounded , I wouldn't order it. Bacon fried rice just like rice mix with sweet and spicy sauce , I didn't find even one sliced bacon. $10.63 for this ,not worth it.
author: Linda L.

description: I tried the cup bob the meat o top of rice and it was one of those experiences where the first few bites were ok, quite a tangy sauce but I quickly grew tired of the overwhelming flavors, too much spice and salt, it was really oily and I felt gross afterwards
author: Jon R.
